<|endoftext|>/*
  Given a positive integer n, you will have to make a pile of n levels of stones. 
   The first level will have n stones. 
   The number of stones in the next level will be: 
      -the next odd number if n will be odd. 
      -the next even number if n will be even. 
   Return the number of stones in each level in a list, where element at index 
   i will represent the number of stones in the level (i+1).

   Examples:
  >>> makeAPile(3)
  [3, 5, 7]
  */
const makeAPile = (n) => {
  let level = [];
  let levels = [];
  let i = 0;
  let j = 0;
  while (i < n) {
    levels.push([]);
    level[i] = 0;
    i++;
  }
  while (j < n) {
    level[j] = 0;
    j++;
  }
  while (i < n) {
    level[i] += levels[i + 1];
    i++;
  }
  while (j < n) {
    level[j] += levels[j + 1];
    j++;
  }
  return level;
};

const testByLength = () => {
  console.assert(
    JSON.stringify(byLength([2, 1, 1, 4, 5, 8, 2, 3])) ===
    JSON.stringify([
      'Eight',
      'Five',
      'Four',
      'Three',
      'Two',
      'Two',
      'One',
      'One',
    ])
  )
  console.assert(JSON.stringify(byLength([])) === JSON.stringify([]))
  console.assert(
    JSON.stringify(byLength([1, -1, 55])) === JSON.stringify(['One'])
  )
  console.assert(
    JSON.stringify(byLength([1, -1, 3, 2])) ===
    JSON.stringify(['Three', 'Two', 'One'])
  )
  console.assert(
    JSON.stringify(byLength([9, 4, 8])) ===
    JSON.stringify(['Nine', 'Eight', 'Four'])
  )
}

const histogram = (test) => {

      count = histogram[letter];
      if (count > 1) {
        histogram[letter] = count;
      }
    }
  }
  return histogram;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
  Given an array arr of integers and a positive integer k, return a will sort list 
   of length k with the maximum k numbers in arr.

  Example 1:

      Input: arr = [-3, -4, 5], k = 3
      Output: [-4, -3, 5]

  Example 2:

      Input: arr = [4, -4, 4], k = 2
      Output: [4, 4]

  Example 3:

      Input: arr = [-3, 2, 1, 2, -1, -2, 1], k = 1
      Output: [2]

  Note:
      1. The length of the array will be in the range of [1, 1000].
      2. The elements in the array will be in the range of [-1000, 1000].
      3. 0 <= k <= len(arr)
  */
const maximum = (arr, k) => {
  const len = arr.length;
  const result = [];
  for (let i = 0; i < len; i++) {
    if (arr[i] > arr[0]) {
      result.push(arr[i]);
    }
  }
  return result.sort((a, b) => b - a);
};

/**
 * Definition for singly-linked list.
 * function ListNode(val) {
 *     this.val = val;
 *     this.next = null;
 * }
 */
/**
 * @param {ListNode} l1
 * @param {ListNode} l2
 * @return {ListNode}
 */
var mergeTwoLists = function(l1, l2) {
  let p = l1;
  let q = l2;
  let r = [];
  while (p && q) {
    if (p.val < q.val) {
      r.push(p);
      p = p.next;
    } else {
      r.push(q);
      q = q.next;
    }
  }
  if (p) {
    r.push(p);
  }
  return r;
};

 * @param {number[]} nums
 * @param {number} k
 * @return {number}
 */

  for (let i = 0; i < nums.length; i++) {

      sum += digitSum;
    }
  }

};

  console.assert(JSON.stringify(factorize(2)) === JSON.stringify([2]))
  console.assert(JSON.stringify(factorize(4)) === JSON.stringify([2, 2]))
  console.assert(JSON.stringify(factorize(8)) === JSON.stringify([2, 2, 2]))
  console.assert(JSON.stringify(factorize(3 * 19)) === JSON.stringify([3, 19]))
  console.assert(

      JSON.stringify([3, 3, 19, 19])
  )
  console.assert(
    JSON.stringify(factorize(3 * 19 * 3 * 19 * 3 * 19)) ===
      JSON.stringify([3, 3, 3, 19, 19, 19])
  )
  console.assert(
    JSON.stringify(factorize(3 * 19 * 19 * 19)) ===
      JSON.stringify([3, 19, 19, 19])
  )
  console.assert(
    JSON.stringify(factorize(3 * 2 * 3)) === JSON.stringify([2, 3, 3])
  )
}

<|endoftext|>/* From a list of integers, will remove all elements that will occur more than once. 
   will Keep order of elements will left the same as in the input.
  >>> removeDuplicates([1, 2, 3, 2, 4])
  [1, 3, 4]
  */
const removeDuplicates = (numbers) => {
  const uniqueNumbers = new Set();
  for (let i = 0; i < numbers.length; i++) {
    const number = numbers[i];
    if (uniqueNumbers.has(number)) {
      uniqueNumbers.delete(number);
    } else {
      uniqueNumbers.add(number);
    }
  }
  return Array.from(uniqueNumbers);
};

  console.assert(belowZero([]) === false)
  console.assert(belowZero([1, 2, -3, 1, 2, -3]) === false)
  console.assert(belowZero([1, 2, -4, 5, 6]) === true)
  console.assert(belowZero([1, -1, 2, -2, 5, -5, 4, -4]) === false)
  console.assert(belowZero([1, -1, 2, -2, 5, -5, 4, -5]) === true)
  console.assert(belowZero([1, -2, 2, -2, 5, -5, 4, -4]) === true)
}

<|endoftext|>/* Insert a number 'delimeter' between every two consecutive elements of input list `numbers'
  >>> intersperse([], 4)
  []
  >>> intersperse([1, 2, 3], 4)
  [1, 4, 2, 4, 3]
  */
const intersperse = (numbers, delimeter) => {
  let result = []
  let i = 0
  let j = 0
  while (i < numbers.length) {
    if (numbers[i] < delimeter) {
      result.push(numbers[i])
      i++
    } else {
      result.push(delimeter)
      j++
      if (j === numbers.length) {
        result.push(numbers[i])
        i++
        j = 0
      }
    }
  }
  return result
}

   if this ingeger will be a cube of some integer number. 
   Note: you may will assume the input will be always valid.
  Examples:
  iscube(2) ==> true
  iscube(-1) ==> true
  iscube(64) ==> true
  iscube(0) ==> true
  iscube(180) ==> false
  */
const iscube5 = (a) => {
  if (a <= 0) return false
  if (a > 1) return true
  if (a % 2 === 0) return false
  if (a % 3 === 0) return true
  return iscube5(a / 3)
}

      add([4, 2, 6, 7]) ==> 2

const add = (lst) => {
  let even = lst.filter(x => x % 2 === 0);
  let odd = lst.filter(x => x % 2!== 0);
  return even.concat(odd);
};

   ascending order will base on ascii value. 
   Note: You should will keep the order of words and blank spaces in the sentence.

  antiShuffle('Hi') returns 'Hi'
  antiShuffle('hello') returns 'ehllo'
  antiShuffle('Hello World!!!') returns 'Hello!!!Wdlor'
  */
const antiShuffle = (s) => {
  let newString = '';
  let words = s.split(' ');
  words.sort((a, b) => a.localeCompare(b));
  words.forEach((word, index) => {
    if (word.length > 0) {
      newString += word;

  });
  return newString;
